content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked it too

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it, the test cases are pretty, the task is simple and clear.

I've never heard of the bdpq effect before, are the tiles going to exclusively contain the letters "bdpq/\"? If not is there special case for non-bdpq characters? Is there a chart of these characters somewhere? A brief google only reveals language pathology texts

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I find this little exercise nice and well written. I think it is worth coding. Well done, Lisa.
Looks like some clear enough instructions to me, what programming language do you recommend to solve it?

Come on y'all.  It's not too late to give me those Sweet Sweet Approvals.

Look at the differences in output of this one vs the original. 
These outputs are so much prettier, due to the much-heightened symmetry. 
And that's gotta count for something :)

There are surely plenty of folks who would solve the original and then (like me) have to think thru and make changes to solve this one.
(Just because it's a simple change for some coders doesn't mean it's not a learning experience for others)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Hi Lisa,
I am very sorry, and don't want to be rude. You have a lot of wonderful puzzles ideas, and i loved every single one of them. However, This one is exactly the same your other puzzle "Tile a Floor", except for the mirrored characters. I have only one line of code to change to have a solution for this.
Maybe i'm wrong, but i think two different puzzles should differ more than that. It's my opinion and if any doesn't agree please explain to me if there is any rule on that.
If i am wrong and doing two very similar puzzles is allowed, well, i'll approve it.

Good Job guy !
I trust something like this help us to devellop our knowledge otherwise of a simple code. 
I want to play it in the Clash of code with my classmate.

Oh, didn't know there would be a Part 2 coming. Would it be better to remove Flip/Mirror patterns from Part 1? I haven't tried solving the puzzles, but my gut feeling is that only a few lines to add b, d, p and q to the Part 1 solution code to pass Part 2 (or maybe I'm wrong).

It's a bit unexpected that Part 2 totally removes the need to handle the other symmetries encountered in Part 1. Maybe it's ok. I don't know.

It may be a good idea to add "(Part 1)" to the title of the other puzzle. Or maybe instead of "(Part 1)" and "(Part 2)", distinguish the puzzles by the symmetry types instead.

Constraints section
* Please delete the word "Constraints".

* Please change N to "[[quarterSize]]".

Thanks.

Thanks as always for the great and timely feedback.  

I actually didn't know that "Part 2" was coming either.  I was just looking thru my old notebooks and saw I had this idea scribbled down at one point and so I thought I would implement it. 

And since it was so similar to something I had just done, I called it part 2, but now I'm thinking this one is done by a competing Tile-company and I'll make that the narrative.  

For me, it took more than a few lines to make this different than "Part 1", since that bdqp patterning is more complicated.

At some point I might do a "medium" puzzle that does Part 1 and Part 2 together, but that is a task for a far future day.

Thanks for the feedback, including the kind phrasing.

My counter-argument would be: 
I grant you that a great programmer would be able to solve both with few changes, but "easy" puzzles are not targeted toward great programmers.

To give you background on my thought process in creating my puzzles:  I (personally) didn't know how to solve this one before I created it.  (And thus I was intrigued enough to figure it out and create the puzzle.)

In other words, even though I (created and) solved the original Tile A Floor, this was different enough for me, that I definitely couldn't immediately solve it.
For no good reason at all, I recommend C#... because that is what I know
Please always type a comment when you approve or reject a contribution. Thanks.

Hi iggy --

Thanks for the feedback, and sorry for the confusion.

The "bdpq effect" is just a phrase that I made up to summarize the idea that:
b is a mirror-reflection of d
d is a flip-reflection of q
q is a mirror reflection of p
p is a flip-reflection of b

I have now re-phrased part of the puzzle to now say:
"specializing in what you call the bdpq-effect"

Hopefully that clarifies that it's just a made-up summary-phrase

Other non-slash/non-bdqp chararacters just follow the general rule of "the quadrants of a Tile are mirror/reflections of each other"
Thank ya thank ya
Done :)
Thanks

Same code, just changing the conditions of symetry.
Actually, i feel a bit shameful, because of the effort you put into making nice puzzles. I'll maintain that the puzzle is too similar
(But the ascii tiles are really nice).

If i can give you an idea, you could do a puzzle titled "broken tiles", where you have part of a drawing and the challenge would be to rebuild the initial pattern which was broken, by filling the missing parts using the symetry. Like, reversing this exercice with blank spots. Could be fun, while being different, and maybe you don't have much to change ;)
Oooohhh, I like that !!

Also, don't feel "shameful".
Of course I love all my "puzzle-babies" but also I understand that its part of the process to be able to accept constructive feedback, so I do thank you for the feedback.  It's valuable.

I learn lots --and get plenty of dopamine-hits :) -- creating the puzzles, so for me they are worth the time and effort, even if they aren't ultimately universally loved.
I like Razovsky's idea too! That'll make this puzzle much more distinct.
I've added the word "Next" in Input section just now.
